feed.title: Current Watches, Warnings and Advisories for New Zealand issued by MetService

entry.title: Heavy Rain Warning - Orange
entry.summary: Expect 100 to 150 mm of rain. Peak rates of 20 to 30 mm/h expected Tuesday morning. Impact: Streams and rivers may rise rapidly. Surface flooding, slips, and difficult driving conditions possible. Chance of upgrading to a Red Warning: Minimal. Changes: Watch upgraded to an Orange Warning.

author.name: Meteorological Service of New Zealand Limited

entry.title: Heavy Rain Warning - Orange
entry.summary: Expect 50 to 80 mm of rain, especially about the ranges. Thunderstorms possible. Peak rates of 15 to 25 mm/h expected tonight and overnight. Impact: Streams and rivers may rise rapidly. Surface flooding, slips, and difficult driving conditions possible. Chance of upgrading to a Red Warning: Minimal.

author.name: Meteorological Service of New Zealand Limited

entry.title: Heavy Rain Warning - Orange
entry.summary: Expect 100 to 150 mm of rain, with possible thunderstorms. Peak rates of 20 to 30 mm/h expected late afternoon and evening. Impact: Streams and rivers may rise rapidly. Surface flooding, slips, and difficult driving conditions possible. Chance of upgrading to a Red Warning: Minimal.

author.name: Meteorological Service of New Zealand Limited

entry.title: Heavy Rain Warning - Orange
entry.summary: Expect 70 to 110 mm of rain on top of what has already fallen. Thunderstorms possible. Peak rates of 20 to 30 mm/h expected this afternoon and evening. Impact: Streams and rivers may rise rapidly. Surface flooding, slips, and difficult driving conditions possible. Chance of upgrading to a Red Warning: Minimal.

author.name: Meteorological Service of New Zealand Limited

entry.title: Heavy Rain Warning - Orange
entry.summary: Expect 120 to 150 mm of rain, with possible thunderstorms. Peak rates of 20 to 25 mm/h expected this evening and overnight. Impact: Streams and rivers may rise rapidly. Surface flooding, slips, and difficult driving conditions possible. Chance of upgrading to a Red Warning: Minimal.

entry.title: Heavy Rain Warning - Orange
entry.summary: Expect 70 to 90 mm of rain, with possible thunderstorms. Peak rates of 15 to 20 mm/h expected this afternoon and evening. Impact: Streams and rivers may rise rapidly. Surface flooding, slips, and difficult driving conditions possible. Chance of upgrading to a Red Warning: Minimal.

author.name: Meteorological Service of New Zealand Limited

entry.title: Heavy Rain Warning - Orange
entry.summary: On top of what has already fallen, expect 90 to 120 mm of rain about the main divide, and 60 to 90 mm within 20 km farther east. Peak rates of 20 to 30 mm/h expected this afternoon about the divide. Freezing level about 2000 metres. Impact: Streams and rivers may rise rapidly. Surface flooding, slips, and difficult driving conditions possible. Chance of upgrading to a Red Warning: Minimal.

author.name: Meteorological Service of New Zealand Limited

entry.title: Heavy Rain Warning - Orange
entry.summary: Expect 110 to 150 mm of rain on top of what has already fallen. Peak rates of 20 to 30 mm/h expected this afternoon. Impact: Streams and rivers may rise rapidly. Surface flooding, slips, and difficult driving conditions possible. Chance of upgrading to a Red Warning: Minimal.

author.name: Meteorological Service of New Zealand Limited

entry.title: Heavy Snow Warning - Orange
entry.summary: Heavy rain is expected to develop this morning, then turn to a period of heavy snow this afternoon and evening. Expect 10 to 15 cm of snow to settle above 500 metres, but 20 to 30 cm above 800 metres about the Mackenzie Basin and northern parts of Otago. Impact: Travel disruption and damage to trees and powerlines possible. Cold conditions may cause stress for livestock. Chance of upgrading to a Red Warning: Minimal. Changes: Warning area extended to include northern parts of inland Otago.

author.name: Meteorological Service of New Zealand Limited

entry.title: Strong Wind Warning - Orange
entry.summary: Severe gale northwesterlies gusting 120 km/h in exposed places. Impact: Damage to trees, powerlines, and unsecured structures possible. Driving may be difficult, especially for high-sided vehicles and motorcycles. Chance of upgrading to a Red Warning: Minimal.

author.name: Meteorological Service of New Zealand Limited

entry.title: Strong Wind Warning - Orange
entry.summary: Severe gale northwesterlies gusting 120 km/h in exposed places. Impact: Damage to trees, powerlines, and unsecured structures possible. Driving may be difficult, especially for high-sided vehicles and motorcycles. Chance of upgrading to a Red Warning: Minimal. Changes: Watch upgraded to an Orange Warning.

entry.title: Strong Wind Warning - Orange
entry.summary: Severe gale northerlies with damaging gusts of 130 km/h in exposed places. Impact: Damage to trees, powerlines, and unsecured structures possible. Driving may be difficult, especially for high-sided vehicles and motorcycles. Chance of upgrading to a Red Warning: Low.

entry.title: Heavy Rain Watch
entry.summary: Periods of heavy rain, with thunderstorms. Rainfall amounts may approach, or possibly exceed, warning criteria in localised areas. Chance of upgrading to a Warning: Moderate.

entry.title: Road Snowfall Warning
entry.summary: Snow showers lowering to 800 metres, with 1 to 2 cm possibly settling on the road above this level.

entry.title: Road Snowfall Warning
entry.summary: A few snow showers are possible on Tuesday, and 3 to 5 cm may settle on the road above 600 metres from early morning through to early evening.

entry.summary: Expect 10 to 20 cm of snow to accumulate above 500 metres, with lesser amounts at lower levels.

entry.summary: Expect 6 to 12 cm of snow to accumulate above 700 metres with lesser amounts down to 400 metres. Snow should ease for a time overnight tonight

entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch
entry.summary: An active front is forecast to move eastwards across the upper North Island before dawn on Tuesday morning, bringing a burst of heavy rain and possible thunderstorms. There is a moderate risk of LOCALISED DOWNPOURS of 25 to 40 mm/h with the passage of this front and any associated thunderstorms. Rainfall of this intensity can cause surface and/or flash flooding, especially about low-lying areas such as streams, rivers or narrow valleys, and may also lead to slips.

author.name: Meteorological Service of New Zealand Limited
